headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Facebook Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call will be recorded. Thank you very much. Miss Debor
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Facebook Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call will be recorded. Thank you very much. Miss Deborah Crawford, Facebook's Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Facebook's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me today to discuss our results are Mark Zuckerberg, CEO; Sheryl Sandberg, COO; and Dave Wehner, CFO. Before we get started, I wou
componenttext:
Thank you. 
Good afternoon, and welcome to Facebook's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me today to discuss our results are Mark Zuckerberg, CEO; Sheryl Sandberg, COO; and Dave Wehner, CFO. 
Before we get started, I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that our remarks today will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause these results to differ materially are set forth in today's press release, our annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC.  Any forward-looking statements that we make on this call are based on assumptions as of today, and we undertake no obligation to update these statements as a result of new information our future events. 
During this call, we may present both GAAP and not the financial measures. The reconciliation of captain on GAAP measures is included in today's earnings press release. The press release and an accompanying investor presentation are available on our website at investor.fb.com. And now I'd like to turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. Overall, Q4 was a strong quarter and a great end to the year. More than 1.59 billion people now use Facebook each month and 1.04 billion every day, a growth of nearly 200 million people monthl
componenttext:
Thanks, Deborah, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. 
Overall, Q4 was a strong quarter and a great end to the year. More than 1.59 billion people now use Facebook each month and 1.04 billion every day, a growth of nearly 200 million people monthly and 148 million people daily this year. More than 1.44 billion people use Facebook on mobile devices. 
When it comes to our business, we're also pleased with our continued growth. Total revenue grew by 52% year-over-year to more than $5.8 billion, and advertising revenues grew by 57% to reach more than $5.6 billion. 
But it's important to consider not just our business results, but also how we're improving the lives of people and communities around the world. Next week, Facebook celebrates its 12th birthday. And as I think about our progress and where we go from here, I have reflected on the diverse global moments that Facebook was involved in 2015. 
More than 950 million people received a notification that a friend or a loved one was safe in a crisis. Millions of people supported the people of Nepal after the earthquake and the people of France after the Paris attacks. More than 8 million people used 35,000 Groups and Pages on Facebook to support refugees. And people from all over the world connected around moments from Star Wars to the U.S. presidential election, from the Indian Super League to the Cricket World Cup.
Seeing our global community connecting in all these ways shows the opportunities ahead as we connect the world, but also the challenges. Even as the world has tended towards greater openness over time, in many communities, we also see greater fear over what a connected world and more technological progress means for them. Addressing these concerns is essential for making progress on our mission. And we're going to keep working to give as much voice as we can and advance the benefits of connectivity and bringing the world together.  In 2016 and beyond, we're going to continue doing that by serving our community, working to bring connectivity to billions of people not yet connected and building technologies that give people more ways to express themselves. 
Now let's talk about how we've continued working to do that, and let's start with how we're improving our existing products and businesses.  Our strategy here is to deliver better, more engaging experience for our community and to give people better tools to sharing different types of content with a different groups of people that they care about. Video is an important part of the Facebook experience, and continuing to invest here is important for allowing people to share some of the most engaging content. We've continued to make progress and now, 100 million hours of video are watched daily on Facebook. We've been testing new experiences like Suggested Videos, which enables people to discover more videos that they might be interested in. We're also exploring ways to get people a dedicated place on Facebook for when they just want to watch videos.
With other parts of our core, we've continued to focus on improving the performance and quality of our product to better serve different communities on Facebook. And these efforts are paying off, with growth and engagement for different products reaching an impressive scale. Now more than 500 million people use Events each month, and more than 123 million events were created on Facebook in 2015. 
For the first time, more than 1 billion people used Groups in a single month on Facebook. It's inspiring to see all the different communities using Groups from small family and classroom and church groups to large ones, like the Running Challenge Group that I started a few weeks ago that now has about 100,000 members. 
To serve our entire global community, we're optimizing our services for people in developing countries. We've improved Facebook Lite to offer a better experience in low-bandwidth environments, improving load times and adding features like video. More than 80 million people now use Facebook Lite as of December. 
And when it comes to serving businesses, we've continued to focus on creating better ads and tools for more than 2.5 million active advertisers. More than 50 million small businesses now use Pages on Facebook, and people post than 2.5 billion comments on these pages each month. It's a good example of how the strength and engagement of our community is making Facebook more valuable for businesses every day, as Sheryl is going to talk about this in a minute.
Next, let's talk about how we're building our next generation of services. With Facebook, we've continued to drive the shift towards more visual content online. The community continues to grow. And back in September, we announced a new milestone of 400 million monthly actives. Over the last year, after community has grown, we focused on building engaging new experiences for the community, including by improving search and by introducing trending content. 
We've also worked to develop new experiences to give people more options by creating and sharing different types of content. In March, we launched  app, allowing people to combine images. And in October, the team also launched Boomerang, an app for making videos, which reached #1 in the App Store in more than 70 countries.  We also introduced a new video channel on Instagram to watch moments from big events like New Year's or the college football championship as they happen. 
With Messenger and WhatsApp, we've continued to make progress with building these in two valuable communication services for everyone in the world. More than 800 million people now use Messenger monthly. And in 2015, we grew that number by almost 0.25 billion, while also increasing engagement. We continue to give people who is to communicate by introducing video calling and new options for customizing conversations with fun things like colors and , using apps like Messenger platform.
We also worked to expand Messenger's utility by adding payments, a new way to connect with businesses, and by testing M, a digital assistant powered by AI. In this quarter, we also began testing a transportation platform, allowing people to request an Uber ride. More services will be coming to the platform soon, including airlines.
WhatsApp ended the year with nearly 1 billion monthly actives. As WhatsApp has grown, we worked to keep it fast, simple and reliable. And we've seen many communities come to depend on this as their main communication service. To serve these communities well, this month we announced that WhatsApp will now be free to everyone and will no longer charge subscription fees that many people were charged after their first year. We think this is an important step towards creating an even more ubiquitous product without affecting our plans for building WhatsApp into an important business in the coming years. Later this year, we'll be testing new ways to people use WhatsApp to communicate with businesses and organizations that they want to hear from.
Finally, let's talk about our work on the breakthrough technologies that can help connect more people to the Internet and create transformative new experiences. In 2015, we made significant progress on our efforts to connect more people to the Internet. We launched the first trial of Express WiFi, a product designed to help entrepreneurs bring their communities online. We launched free basics in 33 more countries now connected 19 million people. This year, we expect to hold our first test flight of Aquila, our first solar-powered aircraft designed to beam Internet into communities from the sky. And we're also working on new advances in lasers that can transfer large amounts of data faster and more efficiently than anything today.
With our work in AI, we continue to make progress towards the new generation of computers that can see and understand. Over the last year, we published dozens of research papers, including some of the leading work on image recognition and language understanding. To drive the entire AI community forward, we've also open sourced software and allotted new AI hardware platform. Achieving the scientific breakthroughs to build AI that makes a dramatic visible difference in people's lives is going to take a long time, but already we're seeing opportunities to serve our community. We recently built a prototype AI system that combines language and vision comprehension, so you can show an image that has never been seen before and it can answer questions about that image. And we've even used AI to help blind people experience their friends' photos and News Feed by describing the scenes.
with virtual reality, we've reached some important milestones. The Samsung VR shipped over the holidays with our Oculus software, and we're pleased with the initial reaction. This month, we also opened preorders for Oculus headsets. This will be the world's best VR experience, and we're excited to begin shipping to people in more than 20 countries before the end of March. More than 100 VR games and experiences have come to Oculus this year. And later this year, we'll also be shipping our Oculus touch controllers to give headset virtual reality. These controllers will enhance the VR experience and allow people to communicate more naturally in VR through intuitive hand movements and gestures. 
This Oculus launch is shaping up to be a big moment for the gaming community, but over the long term, VR has the potential to change the way that we live, work and communicate as well. The launch is an important step towards the future, and we're really looking forward to seeing how people use it.
So that's how we've continued to make progress on our strategy. It's been a strong quarter, and we ended 2015 with a great foundation for our efforts going into 2016. Our strategy is working, and we have many more opportunities ahead. So we're going to continue investing to deliver more great results over the long term.
On a more personal note, over the last few months with new addition in my family, I've been reflecting a lot on the legacy that we want to pass on to the next generation. I'm excited about our progress and the chance to build something great for the future. If we continue to focus on solving the fundamental challenges facing the world and bringing the world closer together, we can leave a better world for the whole next generation.
And that's what I think about every day as we continue building Facebook. And I want to thank everyone in our community, replaced, our shareholders from our partners for helping us on this journey. Thanks, and here's Sheryl.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Mark, and hi, everyone. We had a terrific fourth quarter capping off a great 2015. Q4 ad revenue grew 57% or 66% on a constant-currency basis. Mobile ad revenue reached $4.5 billion, up 81% year-over-year and is now 80% of total ad revenue.Fac
componenttext:
Thanks, Mark, and hi, everyone. 
We had a terrific fourth quarter capping off a great 2015. Q4 ad revenue grew 57% or 66% on a constant-currency basis. Mobile ad revenue reached $4.5 billion, up 81% year-over-year and is now 80% of total ad revenue.
Facebook and Instagram drive business results for our partners, helping their products off shelves online and off. As a result, we're growing spend from our current clients and attracting new marketers to our platform. We saw strong growth across all verticals and marketer segments and regions. We're also pleased with the growth we're seeing in the emerging markets and countries like China, where businesses are advertising on Facebook and Instagram to reach people internationally. We continue to make progress in our 3 priorities: capitalizing on the shift to mobile, growing the number of marketers using our ad products, and making our ads more relevant and effective.
First, capitalizing on the shift to mobile. Heading into 2016, it's clear that consumers have shifted to mobile and businesses know they need to catch up. Marketers now realize that if they want to reach their customers where they are, mobile is essential. Our conversations with clients have shifted from if they should market on mobile to how. With over 1.44 billion people using Facebook on mobile monthly and over 400 million monthly actives on Instagram, Facebook and Instagram have become the 2 most important mobile advertising platforms. We provide a creative canvas powered by technology, a unique combination of art and science that marketers can use to deliver great creatives with the highest quality targeting at unparalleled scale.
The 2015 holiday season was a defining moment for mobile marketing and demonstrated the power of our mobile platform. According to comScore, total U.S. consumer spending on mobile in November and December was up 59% year-over-year. This holiday season, marketers turned to mobile more than ever before.  To reach a large mobile audience for the launch of Halo 5, Microsoft Xbox used Facebook and Instagram. Working with their agencies and power media team from Network, Eisenberg Group and McCann, they understood that people watch people differently on mobile News Feed and on TV. So they created videos to capture audience attention in the first 3 seconds even without sound. They drove over 380 million impressions and 49 million video views in key markets and increased purchase intent by 10 points in the U.S.
Our second priority is growing the number of marketers using our ad products. Last quarter, we announced that we had over 2.5 million active advertisers, and since then, our growth has remained strong. This represents a small fraction of the over 50 million small businesses now actively using Pages, so we see a big opportunity to continue to grow the number of Facebook advertises going forward. We're also very please with growth in advertiser adoption of Instagram and the positive results that advertisers are seeing from their investments. 98 of the top 100 advertisers on Facebook also advertised on Instagram in Q4.
Our third priority is improving the relevance and effectiveness of our ads. We shipped a lot of new ad products this past year. These products help deliver personalized marketing at scale and drive business for our clients. Leading up to Black Friday, ShopDirect, the U.K.'s second largest online retailer, teased upcoming sales for the cinema graph video to build awareness. They then retargeted people who saw the video with 1-day-only deals. On Black Friday, they used our carousel and PPA ads to promote products people have shown interest in. They saw a 20x return on ad spend from this campaign, helping them achieve their biggest Black Friday and most successful sales day ever. 
To share just a few other product examples and emerging markets, we launched slide show, a video-like ad experience that works with lower connection speeds and feature phones. local awareness at globally to help brick-and-mortar businesses reach people near their stores and started testing canvas ads to help marketers showcase their products in a more immersive way.  We continue to invest in ad tech and are especially pleased with the growth of Audience Network. 
Measurement also remains a critical area of focus. Our measurement tools like conversion lift and the Facebook pixel proved to marketers that we're driving business results and help make their ads more relevant. This year, we saw more advertisers shift from proxy metrics like clicks to business results like digital and in-store sales.
Our results show that the investments we've made over the past few years are paying off, and we see a lot of exciting opportunities ahead. We know we still have a lot of hard work to do. And heading into the new year, we will remain very focused on our top 3 priorities.
I want to take this opportunity to thank our clients around the world for their partnership. Your investment and feedback is critical to making our products better. I also really want to thank the global Facebook teams for your extraordinary dedication to our partner success. hard work and execution is critical to helping us fulfill our mission. Thanks, everyone. 
And now here's Dave.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Sheryl, and good afternoon, everyone. Q4 was a strong quarter and wed up a phenomenal year for Facebook. Full year 2015 revenue was $17.9 billion, up 44% year-over-year or 53% on a constant-currency basis. In 2015, we generated over $6 billion i
componenttext:
Thanks, Sheryl, and good afternoon, everyone. 
Q4 was a strong quarter and wed up a phenomenal year for Facebook. Full year 2015 revenue was $17.9 billion, up 44% year-over-year or 53% on a constant-currency basis. In 2015, we generated over $6 billion in free cash flow including $2.1 billion in Q4, while continuing to fund important investments for the future growth of the business. 
The strong growth and engagement of our community was a consistent theme throughout 2015 and that continues in the fourth quarter. In December, 1.04 billion people used Facebook on an average day, an increase of 17% compared to last year. This daily number represented 65% of the 1.59 billion people who visited Facebook during the month of December.
Mobile continued to drive the growth of our community. In December, 1.44 billion people accessed Facebook on mobile devices, an increase of 21% compared to last year. And 90% of the people who used Facebook on both a monthly and daily basis accessed us via mobile devices.
Now turning to the financials. All of our comparisons are on a year-over-year basis unless otherwise noted. Additionally, our non-GAAP measures exclude stock-based compensation and the amortization of intangible.
In Q4, total revenue was $5.8 billion, up 52% or 60% on a constant-currency basis. Q4 ad revenue was $5.6 billion, up over $2 billion from last year. Year-over-year growth was 57% or 66% on a constant-currency basis.
The strengthening of the U.S. dollar continued to have an unfavorable impact on our revenue in the fourth quarter. Had exchange rates remained constant with Q4 2014 levels, our total revenue would have been approximately $320 million higher.
U.S. and Canada and Asia Pacific continued to be our 2 strongest regions with ad revenue growth of 64% and 57% respectively. Our rest of world and Europe regions grew at 53% and 45% respectively as they were more heavily impacted by currency headwinds.
Mobile ad revenue was $4.5 billion, up 81% from last year and represented 80% of our advertising revenue. For perspective, 3 years ago, the mobile percentage was just over 20%.  Q4 capped off a remarkably successful year for our mobile advertising business where we were able to combine strong growth in ad inventory supply with strong growth in advertiser demand. 
On the supply side, we grew the number of people using Facebook on mobile time spent and ad load. Our ongoing focus on ad quality and relevance enabled us to deliver a better overall mobile ads experience for our users while increasing the number of ad space. In Q4, we also benefited to a lesser extent from increases in ad inventory from Instagram and the Audience Network.
On the demand side, we believe our efforts on targeting and measurement solutions enabled marketers to achieve better business results at better values. This helped us drive strong growth from a broad array of advertisers, including direct response and brand advertisers, large companies and SMBs and both existing and new advertisers. 
Turning now to the overall price volume metrics. In Q4, the average price per ad increased 21%, while total ad impressions increased 29% on a year-over-year basis. It's worth noting that this was the first quarter since Q3 2013 that total ad impressions increased on a year-over-year basis. This was driven by an increase in mobile ad impressions and was partially offset by a decline in ad impressions delivered on personal computers, consistent with the ongoing declines in PC usage.  The reported increase in price is being driven by the continued mix shift towards mobile, which contains higher-priced News Feed ads, rather than the mix we have on PCs on both News Feed ads and lower-priced right-hand column ads.
Total payments and other fees revenue was $204 million, down 21% compared to last year. The decline was driven by reduction in payments revenue related to to games played on personal computers.
Turning now to expenses. Q4 total GAAP expenses were $3.3 billion, up 21%, and non-GAAP expenses were $2.3 billion, up 42%. Our year-over-year GAAP expense growth rate slowed this quarter as we lapped the introduction of stock-based compensation charges associated with the WhatsApp transaction. Non-GAAP expenses were driven by increases in headcount-related costs, cost of revenue and marketing expenses. We ended the year with nearly 12,700 employees, up 38% compared to last year.
Our GAAP operating margin was -- sorry, our GAAP operating income was approximately $2.6 billion, representing a 44% operating margin. Our non-GAAP operating income was $3.5 billion, representing a 60% operating margin. 
Our Q4 GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates were 39% and 36% respectively. Our Q4 GAAP net income was approximately $1.6 billion or $0.54 per share, and our non-GAAP net income was $2.3 billion or $0.79 per share. 
In the full year 2015, capital expenditures were $2.5 billion as we continued to invest in servers, data centers, network infrastructure and office facilities to support the rapid growth of the business.
We ended the year with over $18.4 billion in cash and investments.
Turning now to the outlook. First, some color on revenue. We expect the factors that drove the strong growth of our advertising business in 2015 will continue into 2016. However, we expect to continue to face foreign exchange headwind, especially early in the year, as we will be lapping periods where the dollar was relatively weaker than it is today. More importantly, -- sorry, more broadly, the overall macro environment introduces a level of uncertainty around global growth and exchange rates that could impact our business in 2016. And we do expect to face tougher comparables as the year progresses, given the remarkably strong advertising performance in 2015.
Turning now to expense guidance. 2016 will be another significant investment year for Facebook. In 2015, we continued investing heavily in core. At the same time, we doubled our investment levels in our next-generation services, which includes WhatsApp, Instagram and Messenger. And we tripled our investment levels in our long-term areas of focus, which includes our connectivity efforts, Oculus and our AI investments. We will continue investing significantly in all of these areas in 2016.
We expect the year-over-year growth rate for full year 2016 total GAAP expenses to be approximately 30% to 40%, and for full year 2016 total non-GAAP expenses to be approximately 45% to 55%. Note these ranges represent total operating expenses -- sorry, include cost of revenue. These ranges also include the cost of revenue impact of the expected shipments of Oculus Rift, but we expect that impact to be immaterial to our overall total expenses for the year.
We anticipate our 2016 capital expenditures will be in the range of $4 billion to $4.5 billion. We recently announced that we will begin building a new data center in , Ireland, and that project is on top of the new data center being built in Fort Worth, Texas.
We expect our 2016 stock-based compensation to be in the range of $3.1 billion to $3.3 billion, approximately half of which is related to our prior acquisitions, most notably WhatsApp.  We expect 2016 amortization expenses to be approximately $700 million to $800 million. 
And lastly, we anticipate that our Q1 and full year 2016 GAAP and non-GAAP tax rates to be in the low 30s on a percentage basis, down from our 2015 rates. We expect our tax rates will decline further over time and resemble those of our global peers over the next several years. In addition, in 2016, we expect for the first time to pay a significant amount of U.S  income tax on a cash basis.
To conclude, 2015 was an outstanding year for Facebook. Our performance reflects the strong growth and engagement of our community, the momentum we're seeing in our ads business and the significant progress we're making on our mission to correct the world.
With that, Chris, we would like to open up the call for questions.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth with JPMorgan.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Doug Anmuth with JPMorgan.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two things I wanted to ask, first, Mark, just on Messenger and WhatsApp. Can you just talk more about the takeaway on the Messenger platform, now that it's been open for nearly a year to developers and ho w that's informed your view of what you're going t
componenttext: Two things I wanted to ask, first, Mark, just on Messenger and WhatsApp. Can you just talk more about the takeaway on the Messenger platform, now that it's been open for nearly a year to developers and ho w that's informed your view of what you're going to do with WhatsApp going forward? And then secondly, Dave perhaps or Sheryl on the ad load, a few years ago, we talked about ad load at mid-single-digit levels and then more recently as up significantly since that. do still feel like there's still significant room to increase ad load here? And how do you think about the theoretical ceiling there?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can start with the ad load question, Doug. So ad load is definitely up significantly from where we were a couple of years ago. And as I mentioned, it's one of the factors driving an increase in inventory. Really, one thing to kind of think about here is
componenttext: I can start with the ad load question, Doug. So ad load is definitely up significantly from where we were a couple of years ago. And as I mentioned, it's one of the factors driving an increase in inventory. Really, one thing to kind of think about here is that improving the quality and the relevance of the ads has enabled us to show more of them and without harming the experience and our focus remains on the experience. So we'll continue to monitor engagement and sentiment very carefully. I mentioned that we expect the factors that drove the performance in 2015 to continue to drive the performance in 2016. So yes, I think that's the color I can give on ad load.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On Messenger, the platform efforts in 2015 focused on 2 things. One was expanding the different types of content that people can share in Messenger, and that diversity is going really well. And we see continued increase in video sharing and photos and sti
componenttext: On Messenger, the platform efforts in 2015 focused on 2 things. One was expanding the different types of content that people can share in Messenger, and that diversity is going really well. And we see continued increase in video sharing and photos and stickers and a lot of stuff that you just call fun, but that people really enjoy as different ways to express themselves. But in terms of the business, the more important piece is how people can interact with businesses through Messenger. And we started some early small tests around F8 last year with some e-commerce services people who were buying things, could follow up with the business and get customer support and buy more things. we went through this process of integrating that in making sure that it integrated with all these systems well. I think everyone is still happy with that so far. So we started off pretty slowly, but that's going to be some of the basis for how we look to make Messenger business going forward, and we're happy with the initial results. There's obviously a lot more there than we need to do, and we will have more to talk about this year and beyond.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.
componenttext: The next question is from John Blackledge with Cowen and Company.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So it was a phenomenal quarter and year for Facebook. And given we're about a month into 2016, there's a lot of discussion around the global macro headwinds. wondered how the business is trending thus far in the quarter, maybe by market, U.S., Europe, Asi
componenttext: So it was a phenomenal quarter and year for Facebook. And given we're about a month into 2016, there's a lot of discussion around the global macro headwinds. wondered how the business is trending thus far in the quarter, maybe by market, U.S., Europe, Asia Pac and the rest of the world, and generally, just how Facebook is positioned if the global macro environment softens a bit.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, it's Dave. Just on that question, we're not commenting specifically on Q1. We didn't see anything in Q4 that indicated broad-based macro weakness beyond, of course, the impact that FX is having, which is pretty significant. I mean we saw the im
componenttext: Yes, John, it's Dave. Just on that question, we're not commenting specifically on Q1. We didn't see anything in Q4 that indicated broad-based macro weakness beyond, of course, the impact that FX is having, which is pretty significant. I mean we saw the impact in places like Brazil where you're -- you gotten a currency headwind of over 30%. So you're certainly see that impact and become this sort of global macroeconomic and currency factors will continue to impact us. We're obviously benefiting from a strong secular shift to usage of mobile, and we feel we are very well positioned in that. We're seeing more and more advertisers move to mobile. They realize that it's no longer a question of whether they need to be in mobile, but it's how they're going to be in mobile. And we think we've got the best solution for that. We're investing to make it even better. I think from a secular trend point of view, we're very well positioned. But obviously, we'll continue to monitor the macro conditions and currency.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Eric Sheridan from UBS.
componenttext: The next question is from Eric Sheridan from UBS.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe just asking for more color on Instagram. It sounds as though it's very early days with Instagram. What are you seeing in terms of user engagement as we continue to move ad load up from the product? What advertiser adoption of the product does. I kne
componenttext: Maybe just asking for more color on Instagram. It sounds as though it's very early days with Instagram. What are you seeing in terms of user engagement as we continue to move ad load up from the product? What advertiser adoption of the product does. I knew you give us a bit of color during the prepared comments. And also pricing on the environment inside the platform as you continue to roll out deeper with advertising products.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: When we introduced ads into feed and continue to increase the ad load, we monitor really carefully. We're losing looking at user engagement in the platform. We also look at the quality of ads. And our basic belief is that if we have high-quality ads, thos
componenttext: When we introduced ads into feed and continue to increase the ad load, we monitor really carefully. We're losing looking at user engagement in the platform. We also look at the quality of ads. And our basic belief is that if we have high-quality ads, those create good consumer experience. And we can look at what consumers are doing because we can understand how actively engaged they are on the platform. For Instagram, we don't break out revenue. Instagram, we're pleased with the growth on Instagram. And as I mentioned, 98 of our top 100 advertisers in Facebook are now advertising on Instagram. It's also the case in Facebook with remarkably strong growth as well, servicing strong growth across the platforms. I think what's exciting about both platforms is that we combine the art and the science of both a creative canvas that marketers are excited about and targeting. So to share another example from the holiday, shutter glider their Facebook and Instagram both the brand and direct response holiday campaign on mobile. And what they did was just beautiful pictures, but also targeting them specifically to women with specific interests, such as things like weddings and babies. And they saw a 6.4x return on ad spend. We think that's what's possible when you combine the creative canvas we have, using the technology and using the platform that we've created.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: The next question is from Heather Bellini with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had 2 quick questions. One, Sheryl, I just wanted to follow up on what you said about Facebook and Instagram and the overlap in the advertisers. I was wondering if you can share with us how you feel those advertisers view it. Do they view it as an
componenttext: I just had 2 quick questions. One, Sheryl, I just wanted to follow up on what you said about Facebook and Instagram and the overlap in the advertisers. I was wondering if you can share with us how you feel those advertisers view it. Do they view it as an incremental platform? Or there's been some question about whether or not some advertisers might take their spending and just move it over to Instagram. I'm just wondering if you can see incremental spending as a result of opening both platforms. And the second question with Mark, I'm just wondering. I know you mentioned Oculus and the preorders. I wondering your take on whether or not you're happy with the initial launch of Oculus preorders. And obviously, we also know the big gaming impact, but I'm just wondering from your perspective, as you look out, what industries do you think this could be the most disruptive outside of gaming?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the Oculus one first. Yes, I'm happy. I don't show much joy, but I'm happy. It's going to be gaming from the beginning. That's the initial market. There are about -- I think it's around 250 million people who have XBoxes, PlayStations or Wiis. T
componenttext: I'll take the Oculus one first. Yes, I'm happy. I don't show much joy, but I'm happy. It's going to be gaming from the beginning. That's the initial market. There are about -- I think it's around 250 million people who have XBoxes, PlayStations or Wiis. That's at the initial markets of folks who we think are going to be most interested in the early VR experiences, especially some of the higher price points. But overall, I mean, the reason why were interested in this as a social company is that we think that this is going to be on the way that people interact. And if you tried out the toy box demo with the hands, Oculus Touch, what you see is when you're in virtual reality with another person, you can interact with environment and use your hands. You can -- it's just not about where you are and the fact that you can instantaneously teleport to another place. It's just can interact with people in all these different ways that would be very difficult in the rest of the world. We're very excited about that. That's going to be a big area of investment for us and it's ultimately -- I think it's going to change the way we communicate and live and work, in addition to how we play gains. But I think we're off to a good start.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the Instagram question, certainly on the short run, some of the spend is incremental and some of it isn't. Some of our clients approach this where they have a social budget or a Facebook budget, and some of that moves to Instagram. And some people, it'
componenttext: On the Instagram question, certainly on the short run, some of the spend is incremental and some of it isn't. Some of our clients approach this where they have a social budget or a Facebook budget, and some of that moves to Instagram. And some people, it's incremental spend. In the medium to long run, however, we believe that we are very well positioned to take share from other platforms out there. We believe both Facebook and Instagram have this combination of an ability to do great creatives with the best targeting and the most sophisticated measurement, which shows businesses how we help move products off shelves. And we won, and we tell our clients, to want to be the best dollar, the best euro, the best pound and the best minute you spend. And we really encourage them to measure their ROI and compare us to other platforms. We think that comparison bodes very well for our growth. We also think the continued shift to mobile devices bodes well for our growth as well. That said, we continue to execute. We know this won't be easy. We have to continue to build the right products. We have continue to measure all the way through from seeing ad impression to sale. And so it's up to us to stay focused in the coming year or years.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ben Schachter of Macquarie.
componenttext: The next question is from Ben Schachter of Macquarie.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: You've had a lot of success with stand-alone apps. Should we expect to see launching more such apps? could be the stand-alone video app be a part of that, so that people will want to watch a video? another question, can you just discuss the supply constra
componenttext: You've had a lot of success with stand-alone apps. Should we expect to see launching more such apps? could be the stand-alone video app be a part of that, so that people will want to watch a video? another question, can you just discuss the supply constraints in terms of how many units you can ship per month? And should we expect those shipments to accelerate into the holiday? And also related to that, how are you going to work with retailers to show consumers the power of Oculus in store and in person?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the apps question, the ones that have done the best are things that augment the core Facebook functionality for large subsets of the communities. So for example, we have this Pages Manager app. 50 million businesses that have Pages on Facebook. And
componenttext: So on the apps question, the ones that have done the best are things that augment the core Facebook functionality for large subsets of the communities. So for example, we have this Pages Manager app. 50 million businesses that have Pages on Facebook. And while that is not a huge number compared to the size of the overall community of people, it's a very large number of people and businesses and giving a focused experience for the people who wants to run their business through Facebook and be communicating with the customers all day long. That's just proving to be an incredibly engaging experience that drives content into the system and is good overall. We have introduced a number of things like that for public figures, for Groups. Messenger is probably the most successful. It's something that's connected the Facebook experience that by now, has more than 800 million people using it. So I do think there are additional opportunities for this, and we'll continue looking at them.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Then just following up on VR and supply constraints. So we have 2 products. You've got Gear VR, and Samsung is really  handling all of that from a hardware perspective. And obviously, they're well prepared on that front. With Rift, it's really -- it's ear
componenttext: Then just following up on VR and supply constraints. So we have 2 products. You've got Gear VR, and Samsung is really  handling all of that from a hardware perspective. And obviously, they're well prepared on that front. With Rift, it's really -- it's early in the evolution of VR. It's early to be talking about large volumes. So at this point, I don't think we're giving a lot of color around supply chain and that sort of thing. It's not going to be material to our financials this year.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from Brian Nowak with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2. The first one is to go back to some of core Facebook advertising success. I wondered if you can talk about some of the Facebook video ads learnings, positives you've encountered and hurdles you still encounter that could be holding back advertis
componenttext: I have 2. The first one is to go back to some of core Facebook advertising success. I wondered if you can talk about some of the Facebook video ads learnings, positives you've encountered and hurdles you still encounter that could be holding back advertisers from moving further video budgets out in the platform. And in the second one, we always see this gap between Asia and rest of world monetization versus North America and Europe. I'm just wondering if you can just talk through some strategies in qualitative drivers easy over the last couple of years that is going to increase the overall and rest of world monetization even further.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think our approach and increasing monetization around the world is really the same. We need to build really compelling ad products with great formats that led marketers be creative and the convincing. I'll share an example of something we did for a emer
componenttext: I think our approach and increasing monetization around the world is really the same. We need to build really compelling ad products with great formats that led marketers be creative and the convincing. I'll share an example of something we did for a emerging market. I've mentioned briefly in my remarks Slide Show, the Slide Show product is enabled video-like experience with of lower connection speeds it would feature phones with series of photos. So Coca-Cola used that in Kenya and Nigeria. they took screen shots of a video ad ads they produced in other markets. They uploaded them with text, and it reached 2 million people with a 10-point lift in ad awareness. So the way we need to drive sales around the world is by understanding markets, launching things like click to missed call ads in India and making sure our products work for markets, but also being able to connect to those advertising metrics and business metrics around the world. Video ads are important for our platform. the most important thing that's going well there is consumer engagement with video is growing. We have 500 million people watching video a day. And the fact that so much video is being consumed in our platform consists room from an ads business to grow because we want the formats to match. Marketers also really love video, and it's a really compelling way to reach people and video contributing  to our growth. It's important to note that it's not just large brand advertisers that are using video but all of our market segments, direct response, SMBs who have uploaded 1.5 million videos, and that's both organic and paid in the last month, and developers. The video ad spend is not all incremental, of course, because every time we put an ad in News Feed, it's taking the place of an ad with another format. In terms of learnings, one of the most important learnings we have is that video formats and different on Facebook. There are certainly people that are watching the whole 30-second video ad ads with sound, but there are people very doing less. They're washing shorter formats and they're watching with sound. on one of the challenges we have in the market is convincing marketers and agencies and people that make the video to experiment with different formats. The good news is that we're getting great results like the Halo 5 example I shared in my remarks, that when people are willing to experiment, this is a pretty unique creative canvas. you can do short form with sound off, you can do longer form with sound on, and everything in between. And our ability to persuade marketers to experiment is going to be a major driver of how much we can do here.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: The next question is from Justin Post with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: A longer-term questions. First, I know a year ago, you gave given us a usage update on time spent. wondering if video or any other products are having a big impact on usage, and if you can give us any metrics there. And maybe one for Sheryl. We have you a
componenttext: A longer-term questions. First, I know a year ago, you gave given us a usage update on time spent. wondering if video or any other products are having a big impact on usage, and if you can give us any metrics there. And maybe one for Sheryl. We have you at 8% of all media time spent. I'm just wondering if you think Facebook can monetize better than other forms of media based on time spent or maybe a little bit below. maybe one for Dave, 60% margins last quarter, obviously very strong. I'm just wondering what you think about the long term, and any comments on long-term margins?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of monetizing constant, it's an instance of shifting to a mobile, and businesses need to catch up. the app percentage, we can monetize that. We'll see, but we certainly think that we can continue to benefit from the consumers shift to mobile beca
componenttext: In terms of monetizing constant, it's an instance of shifting to a mobile, and businesses need to catch up. the app percentage, we can monetize that. We'll see, but we certainly think that we can continue to benefit from the consumers shift to mobile because business are behind. If ask even our largest clients, our largest clients, if they draw a pie chart of where the consumer spend time and money and where they spend their time and money, we are still underindexed. That said, say it again, we have a lot of hard work to do. We really need to prove to clients, particularly as the scale and we become a bigger part of their spend, that we're driving results. Other platforms, other forms of advertising like TV and other, have very established metrics that people have believed for a very long time. We think targeting can be better and any other platform. We also believe our ability to measure results and the keeper but it's up to us to prove that and to prove that client to client but it's also worth noting that we worked really well with TV. It's not always the choice of TV or Facebook but asked and we can be a compliment but we've done a bunch of work with Nielsen to measure what happens when marketers do big TV campaigns and do campaigns that are broadly targeted on Facebook, and we are able to increase brand favorability. So for the most part when people are doing big campaigns, they're doing it across multiple platforms, and we think that will continue.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Justin, on time spent, there's no question that video is helping us on time spent and engagement. We don't have any specific steps other than hour per day they -- sorry, time spent per day that Mark mentioned on video. So no updates on stats there other t
componenttext: Justin, on time spent, there's no question that video is helping us on time spent and engagement. We don't have any specific steps other than hour per day they -- sorry, time spent per day that Mark mentioned on video. So no updates on stats there other than that. In terms of our long-term margins, we're not managing the business to a specific margin target in any year. We still think we're early in investing in the business, and we're really investing in new areas today where we see a long-term opportunity for revenue growth. That being said, we do think there's a lot of margin potential in this business, given the focus on advertising, but no target at this point.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.
componenttext: The next question is from Anthony DiClemente with Nomura.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: What is your strategy for professional video content going forward? Talk a lot but video and bring more media content to Facebook, accelerate video engagement adoption. And then for Dave, just kind of back to the quarter. I know you don't break down Insta
componenttext: What is your strategy for professional video content going forward? Talk a lot but video and bring more media content to Facebook, accelerate video engagement adoption. And then for Dave, just kind of back to the quarter. I know you don't break down Instagram revenue and essentials, but wonder if acceleration this quarter would you say was that driven more so by the step up in Instagram giving the opening up the API, the incremental Instagram ad load or was there a comments with exhibition in the quarter Facebook revenue?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of video content, News Feed is as interesting as the quality of the content in it. What we're seeing is that users are generating a lot of high-quality content, often pretty short form that people are really happy to consume. And we believe that
componenttext: In terms of video content, News Feed is as interesting as the quality of the content in it. What we're seeing is that users are generating a lot of high-quality content, often pretty short form that people are really happy to consume. And we believe that trend will continue because we're at the very beginning with people really understanding the power of the smartphones that a lot of people are walking around with particularly in developed markets. We are working with publishers to try to make that content experience better inside of Facebook. The best experience that is probably news with articles where we figured out it was the upload experience. You can have a News Feed to align costs and outside article, so we work with publishers to upload one news article favorably to Facebook, and we're seeing great engagement from that. Similarly, we've had conversations with makers of premium content. I think they're excited by the work they already do with us to use Facebook to distribute their content and we're interested in doing more. It's probably worth noting that much of the engagement and consumption we have a short form, not long form.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Anthony, it's Dave. Instagram, we're pleased with the performance of Instagram. it certainly made contribution this quarter. make no mistake, Facebook, core Facebook is really driving the top line, and we're very pleased with the strong performance t
componenttext: Yes, Anthony, it's Dave. Instagram, we're pleased with the performance of Instagram. it certainly made contribution this quarter. make no mistake, Facebook, core Facebook is really driving the top line, and we're very pleased with the strong performance that we had with Facebook itself in the quarter.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.
componenttext: The next question is from Carlos Kirjner with Bernstein.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 quick questions. I'm interested in the plans to allow users to do other things beyond liking content. I think it call it reactions, or what I call adding more words to the Facebook graph. Can you talk about the rollout of this capability and whet
componenttext: I have 2 quick questions. I'm interested in the plans to allow users to do other things beyond liking content. I think it call it reactions, or what I call adding more words to the Facebook graph. Can you talk about the rollout of this capability and whether you do something you see a Facebook.com or is it going to be widespread across the web much like the like button? And secondly, we can you talk about thinking of the role of different Facebook platforms and payments? Are there things that you will not do because you don't have, or do not want to acquire this assets? And what's boundary for what you can do with the payments?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. Reactions is going to roll it in every platform. We're testing it in a handful of countries to start, just to make sure that we have the UI and interaction simple enough that people could express more of what they wanted without getting in thei
componenttext: Yes, sure. Reactions is going to roll it in every platform. We're testing it in a handful of countries to start, just to make sure that we have the UI and interaction simple enough that people could express more of what they wanted without getting in their way. It is adding a little bit of complexity to something that is very simple today, just one tap Like button. But the philosophy behind it is that when you only have a Like button, if you share a sad piece of content or something that makes you angry, people may not have the tool to react to it. And therefore, over time, the community feels less comfortable sharing that kind of content on Facebook. And we want people to be up to share all the things that are meaningful to them, not just that are happy and people are going to like when they see it. And we think that just really important to the mission of the company and will increase engagement and sharing and openness and all of the things we care about. And so far, I think there are a few teeth that we needed to make to reactions and initially testing it from but it's going well and I think we plan to roll it out everywhere pretty soon, so that's the plan there. On payments, the basic strategy that we have is to make it, especially in products like Messenger that where the business direction is a bit more transactional to take all the friction out that making the transactions that you need. So we don't view ourselves as a payments business. That's not the type of company that we are. We'll partner with everyone who does payments. When you look at the stuff that Apple is doing with Apple Pay for, really need innovation the space that takes a lot of friction out of transactions as well. And our view is that the less friction, the better the user experience, the more people can easily interact with the businesses that they care about. And ultimately for our business, that will drive up the amount that businesses are willing to pay to advertise.  People into those kinds of direction because they perform well. So it's good for everyone, but that's kind of how we think about that.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Michael Nathanson from Moffitt Nathanson.
componenttext: The next question is from Michael Nathanson from Moffitt Nathanson.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2, following up on Mark's answer to the question about payments. I wondered, Sheryl, you look at the fourth quarter as you said, it's a defining moment for marketers. And with the friction of transactions getting easier, was there any kind of shift
componenttext: I have 2, following up on Mark's answer to the question about payments. I wondered, Sheryl, you look at the fourth quarter as you said, it's a defining moment for marketers. And with the friction of transactions getting easier, was there any kind of shift in the marketing or verticals that move money to Facebook in the quarter? Do you see more retailer saying different in terms of the composition of buyers in the quarter?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fourth quarter is a holiday quarter, so our top verticals have -- e-commerce, CPG and retail. Our growth is really broad-based, and I think it really shows how important the targeting can be. What we have definitely been over the past year and plan to inv
componenttext: Fourth quarter is a holiday quarter, so our top verticals have -- e-commerce, CPG and retail. Our growth is really broad-based, and I think it really shows how important the targeting can be. What we have definitely been over the past year and plan to invest even more in the next year is to work hard on vertical specific targeting. So for example, for the telecom industry, being able to target existing consumers with new consumers, with people who are voice plan or data plan about to expire. With the auto industry, the growth for us helping them figure out who their current customer are, what a potential customers are and why are the segments other have 7 likes interest background demographics to their current customers so that they can serve the right ad to the right people. I kind of thinks we're able to do with targeting and measurement apply across industries and obviously have been industry and vertical specific, and we're working hard on that.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Mark Mahaney with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: 2 questions. Sheryl, can you talk about political advertising and how you think about the attractiveness of -- and any thoughts you have on Facebook as a platform for political companies?  And then Mark, story in 2012 at the beginning of the year, you rea
componenttext: 2 questions. Sheryl, can you talk about political advertising and how you think about the attractiveness of -- and any thoughts you have on Facebook as a platform for political companies?  And then Mark, story in 2012 at the beginning of the year, you realized just how powerful the movement was to mobile device. you turned to your engineers and said, "We need to generate 1 billion in revenue off of mobile devices." And I wonder if you've had the same conversation with your engineers when you think about these 2 messaging platforms that you have, that have a large number of uses included globally. We see this shift over its messaging. it's -- the Internet has changed and people have engaged with it. Do you feel like you have, or you need to have that kind of 1 billion conversation with your engineers about those 2 messaging platforms?

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the elections, it's important to note that we're large and diversified, so no one vertical drives our business. Yes, the 2016 elections is a big deal in terms of ad spend, but so is the World Cup. So is the Super Bowl every year. So are events
componenttext: In terms of the elections, it's important to note that we're large and diversified, so no one vertical drives our business. Yes, the 2016 elections is a big deal in terms of ad spend, but so is the World Cup. So is the Super Bowl every year. So are events like . We are excited about the kind of targeting we're able to offer for our ads platform. We believe we have precision that doesn't exist on any other platforms. So for example, using Facebook and Instagram apps, you can target by Congressional district, can target by interest, you can target by demographics or any combination of those. And we're seeing politicians at all level really taking advantage of that targeting. It's also probably worth saying that we're pretty excited about what's happening with the elections organically on Facebook. Facebook's the new town hall. And connecting the people who are running for office, both at and national and the local level, with people directly has been really important. Every member of Congress in the United States is now on Facebook. We're seeing some of them post every vote and explain why they're doing votes. We're seeing a bunch of candidates for president get on Facebook themselves and interact, taking questions from their potential voters directly. And we think that kind of direct engagement where people can hold their elected officials accountable. And elected officials can speak directly to constituent is a really important part of our mission. And we're excited about the 2016 election and what's happening there.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On to the other one, in terms of the story that you said, I think you have it wrong. i don't know where you got the story from. I've never had a conversation with team where we were behind on mobile and I said, "We need to do this to make money." That's n
componenttext: On to the other one, in terms of the story that you said, I think you have it wrong. i don't know where you got the story from. I've never had a conversation with team where we were behind on mobile and I said, "We need to do this to make money." That's not really how we operate. What happened is we realized that mobile was growing faster than the stop and that people were shifting their usage and that it was a more important thing for people's consumer experience. And that's what we made a shift, not in our business for us, but in how we deliver their products. And I told all of my product teams, they come in for reviews come in with mobile. If you come in and try to show me a desktop product, then I'm going to kick you out. You have show me a mobile product. And that I think was just crude leadership tactic, somewhat effective in helping to motivate the organization to shift its energy towards focusing on mobile. But it was, if you remember, we actually went through a pretty tough period. Because we went through this period where our mobile experience was not as good as we wanted to be and we had no ads on mobile. And we actually prioritized making the mobile experience good before putting ads there. So there was a long time where people thought our business might not be as good because we had no ads on mobile. And that was because we always prioritized the experience for people above, even if it's going to be a painful thing for the company. So that's how I think about messaging. We know that messaging is going to be increasingly important. That's why we went out and hired David Marcus. He's one of the best product leaders in the field to run Messenger and when we bought WhatsApp, which is the leading messaging product worldwide. And we have a formula for how we build these businesses. First, you build a great consumer experience, like helps people share a new way, and it's really important. And then after that, you can start to introduce organic ways that people can interact with businesses. So that an Facebook is Pages, the businesses that people want to interact with, the public figures, the politicians, not necessarily as but organic interactions around not necessarily just your friends and families but more public figures and businesses. And once you have that ramped up to a good scale can you really start dialing up advertising and having that feel good and the good part of your experience with good content because all this public figures and businesses are already participating in the platform at scale. So you can expect to see that playbook in Instagram. We're pretty far along in terms of having quite a mature public content ecosystem. And ads are ramping with good high-quality ads because a lot of public figures and businesses are already investing and trading that kind of good content that goes in Facebook Instagram. And you're going to see the same playbook in Instagram and WhatsApp and making stuff that figures and that's a bit more of that in WhatsApp already in terms of Messenger and you're catching up on Messenger, but we'll do that on both and once we have the ecosystem built up, we'll build businesses around that. And that's how we think about stuff and we did in all parts and all the different things that we do going forward.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: The final question is from Paul Vogel with Barclays.
componenttext: The final question is from Paul Vogel with Barclays.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 questions. one, on Facebook Sports stadium, just wondering how you think about that in terms of how it's going to be different from what the different factor and how do you get folks to participate in that? And the second part on the margin side ag
componenttext: Just 2 questions. one, on Facebook Sports stadium, just wondering how you think about that in terms of how it's going to be different from what the different factor and how do you get folks to participate in that? And the second part on the margin side again the year revenue and cost line of geographically? Is there a translation impact to the numbers? But is there any operating mismatch between revenue and costs either benefit or hurt margins.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: On the sports stadium, this is an early test but we're pretty excited about it. We are the largest community of sports fans in the world. We have 650 million sports fans in our platform. And people are already using Facebook to share during real-time even
componenttext: On the sports stadium, this is an early test but we're pretty excited about it. We are the largest community of sports fans in the world. We have 650 million sports fans in our platform. And people are already using Facebook to share during real-time events, an increasingly important use case for us. So this gives people a share -- a place to share that one event and participate in it. I think what you'll see from us is always a focus on driving users and driving engagement. This is one way to do it. We'll see how it works. We're pretty open to experimentation, but we feel pretty confident that real-time sharing is an increasingly important part of the platform and when we continue to invest in.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, it's Dave. I think that question is around sort of FX and how it relates on the revenue side versus the cost side. And on that front, we're -- a substantial majority of our expenses are U.S. dollar based. So certainly, we see an impact to margin
componenttext: And Paul, it's Dave. I think that question is around sort of FX and how it relates on the revenue side versus the cost side. And on that front, we're -- a substantial majority of our expenses are U.S. dollar based. So certainly, we see an impact to margins with FX headwinds. So that's just the reality of having most of our development resources, for instance, in the U.S. So beyond that, we don't do geographic cost breakdowns in our locations. It's not how we run the business, but certainly, from an FX point of view, FX has a dampening effect on margins.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. Thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your time, and we look forward to speaking with you again.
componenttext: All right. Thank you for joining us today. We appreciate your time, and we look forward to speaking with you again.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference call. Thank you for joining us. You may now disconnect your lines.
componenttext: Ladies and gentlemen, this concludes today's conference call. Thank you for joining us. You may now disconnect your lines.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Facebook Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call will be recorded. Thank you very mu
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Chris, and I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Facebook Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Call. [Operator Instructions] This call will be recorded. Thank you very much. Miss Deborah Crawford, Facebook's Vice President of Investor Relations, you may begin.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Facebook's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me today to discuss our results are Mark Zuckerberg, CEO; Sheryl Sandberg, COO; and Dave Wehner, CFO. Before we get started, I would
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon, and welcome to Facebook's Fourth Quarter and Full Year 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Joining me today to discuss our results are Mark Zuckerberg, CEO; Sheryl Sandberg, COO; and Dave Wehner, CFO. 
Before we get started, I would like to take this opportunity to remind you that our remarks today will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially from those contemplated by these forward-looking statements. Factors that could cause these results to differ materially are set forth in today's press release, our annual report on Form 10-K and our most recent quarterly report on Form 10-Q filed with the SEC.  Any forward-looking statements that we make on this call are based on assumptions as of today, and we undertake no obligation to update these statements as a result of new information or future events. 
During this call, we may present both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures. A reconciliation of GAAP to non-GAAP measures is included in today's earnings press release. The press release and an accompanying investor presentation are available on our website at investor.fb.com. 
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Mark.

headline: Facebook, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 27, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Deborah, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. Overall, Q4 was a strong quarter and a great end to the year. More than 1.59 billion people now use Facebook each month and 1.04 billion every day, a growth of nearly 200 million people monthl
componenttext:
Thanks, Deborah, and thanks, everyone, for joining us today. 
Overall, Q4 was a strong quarter and a great end to the year. More than 1.59 billion people now use Facebook each month and 1.04 billion every day, a growth of nearly 200 million people monthly and 148 million people daily this year. More than 1.44 billion people use Facebook on mobile devices. 
And when it comes to our business, we're also pleased with our continued growth. Total revenue grew by 52% year-over-year to more than $5.8 billion, and advertising revenues grew by 57% to reach more than $5.6 billion. But it's important to consider not just our business results, but also how we're improving the lives of people and communities around the world. Next week, Facebook celebrates its 12th birthday. And as I think about our progress and where we go from here, I have reflected on the diverse global moments that Facebook was involved in, in 2015. 
More than 950 million people received a notification that a friend or a loved one was safe in a crisis. Millions of people supported the people of Nepal after the earthquake and the people of France after the Paris attacks. More than 8 million people used 35,000 Groups and Pages on Facebook to support refugees. And people from all over the world connected around moments from Star Wars to the U.S. presidential election, from the Indian Super League to the Cricket World Cup. Seeing our global community connecting in all these ways shows the opportunities ahead as we connect the world but also the challenges. Even as the world has tended towards greater openness over time, in many communities, we also see greater fear over what a connected world and more technological progress means for them. Addressing these concerns is essential for making progress on our mission, and we're going to keep working to give as much voice as we can and advance the benefits of connectivity and bringing the world together. In 2016 and beyond, we're going to continue doing that by serving our community, working to bring connectivity to billions of people who are not yet connected and building new technologies that give people more ways to express themselves. 
Now let's talk about how we've continued working to do that, and let's start with how we're improving our existing products and businesses. Our strategy here is to deliver better, more engaging experiences for our community and to give people better tools for sharing different types of content with the different groups of people that they care about. Video is an important part of the Facebook experience, and continuing to invest here is important for allowing people to share and consume some of the most engaging content. We've continued to make progress and now, 100 million hours of video are watched daily on Facebook. We've been testing new experiences like Suggested Videos, which enables people to discover more videos they might be interested in. We're also exploring ways to give people a dedicated place on Facebook for when they just want to watch videos.
With other parts of our core, we've continued to focus on improving the performance and quality of our product to better serve different communities on Facebook, and these efforts are paying off, with growth and engagement for different products reaching an impressive scale. Now more than 500 million people use Events each month, and more than 123 million events were created on Facebook in 2015. 
For the first time, more than 1 billion people used Groups in a single month on Facebook. It's inspiring to see all the different communities using Groups from the small family and classroom and church groups to the large ones, like the Running Challenge group that I started a few weeks ago that now has about 100,000 members. 
To serve our entire global community, we're optimizing our services for people in developing countries. We've improved Facebook Lite to offer better experience in low-bandwidth environments, improving load times and adding features like video. More than 80 million people now use Facebook Lite as of December. And when it comes to serving businesses, we've continued to focus on creating better ads and tools for our more than 2.5 million active advertisers. More than 50 million small businesses now use Pages on Facebook, and people post more than 2.5 billion comments on these pages each month. It's a good example of how the strength and engagement of our community is making Facebook more valuable for businesses every day, and Sheryl's going to talk more about this in a minute.
Next, let's talk about how we're building our next generation of services. With Instagram, we've continued to drive the shift towards more visual content online. The community continues to grow, and back in September, we announced the new milestone of 400 million monthly actives. Over the last year, as the community has grown, we focused on building engaging new experiences for the community, including by improving search and by introducing trending content.
